answers: Russia [accept Soviet Union or Union of Soviet Socialist Republics]
parts: Name this author of Day of the Oprichnik. He also wrote about a race of blond-haired, blue-eyed people who congregate after the impact of the Tunguska meteorite in the Ice trilogy.
Sorokin is from this country. Yevgeny Zamyatin fictionalized this country’s totalitarian control in his novel We.
This author’s science fiction novels include one where Sharik is turned into the foul-mouthed dogcatcher Poligraf Poligrafovich titled Heart of a Dog.

Splashing water in the shape of a waterfall obscures the title artist who can be seen floating next to three black cats and one of his own paintings in “Dali Atomicus”, a work by this Lithuanian-American photographer.

This American photographer used a sculpture by his friend Auguste Rodin designed as a monument to Balzac for his photograph Towards the Light, Midnight. This artist co-founded the Photo-Secessionist movement with Alfred Stieglitz and organized the influential Family of Man exhibit in 1955.
While visiting his villa at La Rêve, Henri Cartier-Bresson photographed this other artist of Harmony in Red and The Dance as he sat amongst his pet birds in his studio.

answers: Federative Republic of Brazil [or República Federativa do Brasil]
Lampião [or Virgulino Ferreira da Silva; prompt on partial]
Pedro [accept Pedro I or Pedro II]
parts: Name this country where cafe com leite politics dominated during the late 19th and early 20th centuries.

This famous Brazilian bandit or cangaceiro led a group of followers who killed their victims with knives called peixeiras, or “fish-filleters”. He was profiled in Eric Hobsbawm’s study of social banditry.
Brazil’s republic came to be after the overthrow of an emperor with this name. The only two emperors of Brazil both had this regnal name.

answers: PZT [or lead zirconate titanate or PLZT or lead lanthanum zirconate titanate]
ferroelectric random access memory [or FRAM or static/dynamic/non-volatile RAM]
parts: Name this ceramic perovskite material that is ferroelectric at room temperature, in addition to being strongly piezoelectric. Devices made from this material are generally more effective than those made from barium titanate.

The usefulness of PZT also comes from its ability to exhibit this phenomenon at room temperatures. Generally, systems with this property show lag between inputs and outputs due to the system’s physical memory.

One of the most common uses of PZT is within the ferroelectric layer of chips for this most common type of computer memory. This type of memory comes in DIMM and SODIMM sizes and holds data currently in use.

answers: falling off a horse [accept descriptions; accept being crushed by a horse; the word “horse” is required]
parts: Name either of the cousins who fight for the love of Emily in “The Knight’s Tale.”
“The Knight’s Tale” is one of the many stories told by Pilgrims in this collection by Geoffrey Chaucer.
Although he wins Emily’s hand, divine intervention causes Arcite to die in this manner. Elsewhere in the Tales, the Manciple insults the Cook after the very drunk Cook does this action.

answers: Charing Cross Bridge, London [prompt on partial answers]
parts: Name this bridge on the south shores of the Thames next to the Lion’s Brewery, which was painted while one artist was staying in London in the winter of 1906.

Andre Derain’s depiction of Charing Cross Bridge is regarded as one of the premier works of this art movement. This movement’s name was inspired by the critical reception of an Albert Marque sculpture as “Donatello among the wild beasts!”.

The name of Fauvism was coined at the 1905 version of this Salon, which heavily featured works by Derain and Matisse. This salon was created as a middle-ground between the official Salon and the Salon des Independents.

answers: Norbert Weiner [or Wiener process; do not accept Levy process or Poisson process]
parts: Name these sequences of random variables, which at a particular time see the expectation value of the next value in the sequence equal the present value. They were named in reference to an 18th century betting strategy.

Martingales are useful for describing stochastic processes with countable numbers of elements, which are called this type of process in time. Processes described by this adjective are contrasted with continuous-time processes.

Wald’s martingale specifically applies to the continuous-time processes named for this American scientist. This namesake of a measure equivalent to the probability law for continuous functions is also the founder of cybernetics.
Name this goddess who, in Chinese mythology, created humans by flicking a mud-covered rope. She is the consort of Fuxi.

King Zhou’s blasphemy leads to the downfall of the Shang dynasty as Nüwa sends this figure to him as a concubine. This figure sadistically tortured people by making them stand atop a heated bronze cylinder and once ordered a farmer's feet cut off so she could study them.
Daji was one of these animals, which often disguise themselves as beautiful women in East Asian folklore. Meeting one of these animals with nine tails is a sign of good fortune.

answers: John I [accept John I of Castile, John I of Portugal, John I of England]
parts: Name this 1385 battle which resulted in the rise of the Aviz Dynasty.
The Aviz Dynasty was a royal house in this Iberian country.

Both of the kings that fought at Aljubarrota had this regnal name and number. Another king with this name and number lost a battle where he allied with Holy Roman Emperor Otto IV against Philip II of France. Provide both the regnal name and number.

answers: monopsony [accept word forms; accept monopsonistic competition]
parts: Name these policies, which establish the lowest price point at which workers may sell their labor.

In models where the labor market is considered to be this type of market, non-excessive minimum wages are believed to increase efficiency and labor participation. Labor markets of this type face upward sloping labor supply curves where employees act as wage searchers.

The work of these two economists has been used to argue that minimum wages do not hurt employment numbers. These two economists collaborated on the paper "Minimum Wages and Employment," which was later expanded as the book Myth and Measurement.

answers: Léo Delibes [or Clément Philibert Léo Delibes]
left hand pizzicato [accept mano sinistra; DO NOT accept “hammering down”]
parts: Name this technique of plucking the strings of an instrument instead of using a bow.
This composer wrote a commonly-excerpted pizzicato movement in Act III of his ballet Sylvia. The title priestess and her servant Mallika sing a “Flower Duet” in his opera Lakme.
Virtuosic pieces such as Paganini’s 24th Caprice and Sarasate’s Gypsy Airs make use of this type of pizzicato, which is denoted with a + (plus) sign above the note.

answers: Saroyan [accept Aram Saroyan or William Saroyan] (that novel is The Human Comedy)
parts: Give this surname of an author who won a $750 prize for a poem entirely consisting of the misspelled word “lighght.” This surname is shared by his father, who wrote about Homer Macaulay’s childhood in Ithaca, California.
William Saroyan burst onto the scene with a story about an unemployed former trapeze artist set during this economic downturn that began in 1929.
At the end of this 1935 play set during the Great Depression, a union of taxi cab drivers chant “Strike!” after learning the title character has been shot.

answers: bacillus [accept bacillus subtilis or bacillus thuringiensis]
parts: Name this compound. The SacB gene commonly used as a negative selection reporter induces suicide from transformed organisms in the presence of this compound.

The SacB gene originates from the subtilis species of this bacterial genus. The thuringiensis species in this genus of Gram-positive, rod-shaped bacteria is frequently studied for its Cyt and Cry toxins.
B. subtilis produces the stably-folded monomer TasA, a major protein component of these structures, which contain cells bound to a matrix of extracellular polymers adhered onto a surface.
Name this culture to which the Anzick-1 boy belonged. It was named after a New Mexico town.

Dennis Stanford proposed this now widely-discredited hypothesis that the Clovis culture learned how to make their tools through “overshot” flaking taught to them by European peoples of the Upper Paleolithic.
Part of the Solutrean Hypothesis is that the Europeans used one of these structures to travel from Siberia to the Americas during periods of lower sea level.

answers: war [accept a battle; prompt on answers like conflict or fighting]
parts: This text argues that gunas can only affect the ego and have no impact on the spirit. This text outlines the three yoga paths to obtain moksha as jñana (“NYAH-nuh”), bhakti, and karma.

The Bhagavad Gita is framed as a dialogue between Krishna and Arjuna as the latter determines whether to participate in one of these events due to the loss of life it will cause. St. Augustine provided the first defense for the "just" form of these events.

The Bhagavad Gita was consolidated into the doctrine of Advaita Vedanta by this philosopher. This philosopher argued for the unity of Atman and Nigurna Brahman, and discussed the nature of a “brahman without attributes.”

answers: umbrellas [or The Blue Umbrella; or The Umbrellas of Cherbourg]
parts: Name this animation studio behind "Geri's Game." This studio's feature length films include Cars and A Bug's Life, and it was acquired by Disney in 2006.
Domee Shi directed this Pixar short about a Chinese-Canadian woman dealing with empty nest syndrome after her son grows up and moves out. That son is represented by the title steamed bun.

Showings of Monsters University were preceded by a short about a blue one of these objects that becomes separated from his soulmate. Jacques Demy directed a musical titled for these objects that stars Catherine Denueve as Genevieve, who falls in love with a mechanic drafted into the Algerian war.

answers: electric battery [accept lithium-ion battery, primary battery, or secondary battery]
potassium [or K; accept potassium hydroxide or KOH; accept potassium permanganate or KMnO4; prompt on caustic potash]
parts: Name these electrochemical devices that store and release power. UT Austin professor John Goodenough won the 2019 Nobel Prize in Chemistry for developing their lithium-ion variant.

Large grid storage systems commonly make use of “redox flow” batteries containing ions of this metal, since those ions can exist in four distinct oxidation states in solution. Since each oxidation state of this metal is a unique color, its zinc-mediated reduction is a common colorimetric lab experiment.

More conventional lithium-ion alternatives are nickel-cadmium batteries, which use an aqueous solution of this element’s hydroxide as their alkaline electrolyte. Baeyer’s reagent is a compound of this element, oxygen, and manganese.
Name this Osamu Dazai novel, which follows Oda from his time as a child buffoon to an adult morphine addict and alcoholic.
No Longer Human may have been written in response to this other author's death. This author wrote the novel Kappa as well as short stories such as “Hell Screen.”
In 2019, Junji Ito developed a version of No Longer Human in this genre of literature. This Japanese word is used to refer to comic books like Ghost in the Shell and Sailor Moon.
Name this figure. At the age of 72, this figure attained kevalajñāna (kay-vula-nya-nuh) under the asalah tree as the 24th "fordmaker."

Mahavira was the most recent Tirthankara, the semi-mythical leaders of this religion. Members of this faith often wear masks over their mouths and sweep in front of their feet to avoid harming small creatures in accordance with the doctrine of ahimsa.

This figure is represented in the first auspicious dream as a white elephant, signifying his role as a guardian deity. This Vedic god legendarily controls the Panch Kalaya, and in many stories he serves as the teachers of the Tirthankaras.

answers: embalmed beef [prompt on any answer including the terms army and beef with the question “What was the two-word term used for this scandal?”]
parts: Name this scandal, which erupted due to the inattentiveness of Russell Alger towards some low-quality meat.
The embalmed beef scandal took place during this war, in which the US invaded Cuba and Teddy Roosevelt rode with the Rough Riders.

Spanish sailors captured and executed 53 American and British sailors aboard this vessel for shipping arms to Cuba in the build-up to the Spanish-American War. Hamilton Fish extracted an indemnity of $80,000 for the families of the sailors killed aboard this ship.
